case_vignette:
An 9-month-old infant is brought to the physician because of a generalized nonpruritic rash for 2 days. The rash began on her trunk and spread to her extremities. Five days ago, she was taken to the emergency department for fever of 40.5°C (104.9°F) and a 1-minute generalized tonic-clonic seizure. She was born at term and has no history of serious illness. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Current medications include acetaminophen. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F) and pulse is 120/min. Examination shows a maculopapular rash that blanches on pressure. A photograph of the rash is shown. Posterior auricular lymphadenopathy is present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 
A) Erythema infectiosum
B) Roseola
C) D) Rubella
D) E) Fifth disease
E) F) Scarlet fever
F) G) Measles
G) H) Kawasaki disease
H) I) Toxic shock syndrome
I) J) Erythema multiforme
J) K) Stevens-Johnson syndrome
K) L) Toxic epidermal necrolysis
L) M) Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome
M) N) Erysipelas
N) O) Cellulitis
O) P) Impetigo
P) Q) Contact dermatitis
Q) R) Atopic dermatitis
R) S) Psoriasis
S) T) Lichen planus
T) U) Pityriasis rosea
U) V) Pityriasis alba
V) W) Pityriasis rubra pilaris
W) X) Pityriasis versicolor
X) Y) Seborrheic dermatitis
Y) Z) Erythema toxicum neonatorum
Z) AA) Erythema marginatum
AA) BB) Erythema nodosum
BB) CC) Erythema induratum
CC) DD) Erythema multiforme
DD) EE) Erythema gyratum repens
EE) FF) Erythema elevatum diutinum
FF) GG) Erythema annulare centrif
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a generalized rash that started on my trunk and spread to my limbs, and I recently had a high fever and a short seizure.
How old are you?
I am 9 months old.
Has there been any recent illness or infections before these symptoms started?
No, I have no history of serious illness.
Have you been vaccinated according to your age-specific schedule?
Yes, my immunizations are up-to-date.
Is there a history of similar symptoms in your family?
No, there is no such history.
**Final Diagnosis:** Roseola

There is no family history related to these symptoms.
